verb.description: Come into the presence or company of (someone) by chance or arrangement.
examples: a week later I met him in the street
they arranged to meet up that afternoon
the curtains failed to meet in the middle
our eyes met across the table

verb.description: Fulfill or satisfy (a need, requirement, or condition)
examples: this policy is doing nothing to meet the needs of women
they failed to meet the noon deadline

noun.description: An organized event at which a number of races or other sporting contests are held.

examples: it is a theater meet for great events

phrases: the sight that met his eyes was truly amazing
A curious sight met their eyes as they came cautiously around the foremast.
They ran outside, and an incredible sight met their eyes.
The ballroom at the hotel was set for the night and as Natalie and Kate went through its doors a spectacular sight met their eyes.
When they reached the top, all three stable hands were awed by the sight that met their eyes.
origin: Middle English (in the sense made to fit): shortening of Old English gem«£te, of Germanic origin; related to mete.
